bioghist.p: George Vargas was born in Texas to Mexican American parents and later moved to Michigan where he was raised and educated. Like many other working-class Latino youths, Vargas grew up working in the agricultural fields and auto factories. He went on to attend the University of Michigan where he studied under Dr. Diane Kirkpatrick in art history and Black artist and historian Jon Onye Lockard in fine arts. Vargas earned three degrees from the University of Michigan: Bachelor of Fine Arts and Film (BFA '74), Master of Arts in American Culture/Latino Studies (MA '76), and a Ph.D. in American Culture/Art History/Latin American Studies in 1988. His dissertation is titled: "Contemporary Latino Art in Michigan, the Midwest, and the Southwest."

Vargas has gone on to lead a fruitful career where he has held many titles including: artist, muralist, author, art historian and Americanist, museum educator, teacher, lecturer, and arts administrator. In all of his work he continues to be an advocate for multi-cultural art. Vargas has instructed and lectured in various institutions such as University of Texas at El Paso, Oakland University, University of Michigan, the Art Institute of Chicago, and the Detroit Institute of Arts. As an artist and administrator, he has been actively involved with a myriad of art exhibitions, galleries, and conferences across the country since the mid 1970's, especially in Texas and Michigan. He is particularly proud of the "Artist of the Year" award he was given at the 1993 National Council of La Raza Silver Anniversary Conference Art Show in Detroit. His art is also present in may private art collections, including the collection of the late Latino musician Tito Puente.

As an author, Vargas has several publications including: "Mago Gandara: A Woman Muralist at the Border" (monograph, Inter-American and Border Studies, University of Texas at El Paso, 1995), "Border Artists in the Contemporary El Paso Mural Movement: Painting the New Frontier," Chicano Studies: Survey and Analysis (ed. Dennis J. Bixler-Marquez, Kendall/Hunt Publishing Company, Dubuque, Iowa, 1997), "Carlos Lopez: A Forgotten Michigan Painter" (monograph, Julian Samora Research Institute, Michigan State University, East Lansing, Michigan, 1998), "An Update on Chicano Art," Chicano Renaissance: Contemporary Cultural Themes (ed. David R. Maciel, Isidro D. Ortiz, and Maria Herrera-Sobek, University of Arizona Press, 2000), Contemporary Mexican American Art: New Art of the Americas (University of Texas Press, Austin, at press as of 2003), and "Latino Art Timeline and Commentary," Rediscovering America (ed. Carla Blank, Crown Publishing, Oakland, California, 2003). At present Dr. Vargas continues writing and conducting research and has received an educational fellowship to study Jewish culture, religion, and art in Israel.

scopecontent.p: The George Vargas papers present a look at the interests, work, and activities of artist and historian George Vargas. Organized into six series, Personal/Biographical Materials, Conferences and Exhibitions, Research and Professional Activities, Teaching and Education, Papers, Publications, and Non-conference Lectures, and Original Artwork, the papers span the years 1973-2003. The strength of the collection is found in the numerous lectures written by Vargas which reveal the depth of his research, the original artwork, and the broader view of multi-cultural and specifically Latino art activities in Michigan. The researcher should note that many items in the collection overlap various series, and should be sure to look for the "see also" notes which designate these overlaps. Other George Vargas artwork was deposited at the Department of American Culture at the University of Michigan and the University of Michigan Museum of Art.

Conferences and Exhibitions

scopecontent.p: The second series, Conferences and Exhibitions, includes two subseries. The first, Michigan Art Announcements and Publications, holds materials from a number of Michigan art shows and art organizations, and adds to the broad perspective of art activities in Michigan. The next subseries, Individual Conferences and Exhibitions, goes on to document individual art shows and conferences, by date, in Michigan and beyond which George Vargas was involved with either as an artist, administrator, or supporter. Those conferences at which Vargas gave lectures are noted.

Research and Professional Activities

scopecontent.p: The Research and Professional Activities series contains four subseries. The Artists subseries includes materials relating to artists in whom Vargas has particular interest, and in most cases are also Michigan artists. The second subseries, Funding, Organizations, and Proposals, documents projects and organizations with which Vargas had involvement. Also included are funding proposals for projects and research in which Vargas was directly involved or indirectly supported. The Latino Culture and Resources subseries once again touches on the broader Latino art world in Michigan with bibliographies, papers, lists, and directories pertaining to Hispanic and Latino artists and art resources. The fourth and final subseries, Notes from Research and Lectures, contains notes Vargas took while attending lectures by colleagues, and those he took researching at various institutions.

did.unittitle: Teaching and Education

scopecontent.p: The fourth series, Teaching and Education, moves into the realm of the classroom. The series begins with a couple of articles addressing art and multicultural topics in Michigan education, and then goes on to list, by title, various courses taught by Vargas. The particular institution, school, or university where the classes were offered is noted where evident. Included materials range from syllabi and teaching notes to extra credit assignments and exams.

A selection of published artwork by Vargas and descriptions of his work are also included.

Original Artwork

scopecontent.p: The sixth and final series, Original Artwork, contains 2-D artwork by Vargas in a variety of sizes and mediums, and a few items as listed that relate to other materials in the collection. Among the non-Vargas artwork are the Raza Art and Media Collective Journal galley proofs, the Labyrinth of the Americas poster which has text by Vargas, two posters by Jon Onye Lockard, and the Art Show Posters, etc. which correspond with organizations, conferences, and exhibitions in the rest of the collection. The original artwork series is distributed between Box 3, Box 4, three UAl folders, and two tubes.
